ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: The effect of chemical polishing on the interface structure and electrical property of Au/Cd0.9Zn0.1Te contact

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Solidification Processing

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The interface structures between Au electrode and Cd0.9Zn0.1Te wafer with different surface treatments are studied by means of transmission electron microscopy. Before the preparation of the Au film, atomic force microscopy and scanning electron microscopy are employed to investigate the surface morphology and elemental concentration before and after the chemical polishing process. It is found that an amorphous layer with the thickness of approximately 5 nm exists at the interface area for the only mechanical polished samples. As the chemical polishing process goes on, the interfaces become flatter and smoother. A thinner lattice mismatch layer instead of the amorphous layer after the chemical polishing process is found between Au and Cd0.9Zn0.1Te. The formation mechanism for the amorphous layer is considered to be the large lattice mismatch between Au and matrix. Furthermore, current–voltage (I–V) measurement is also carried out to investigate the relationship between the interface structure and electrical properties. The ohmic contact coefficient is calculated to increase from 0.4609 to 1.0904 after 4 min chemical polishing corresponding to the I–V test. It is indicated that the charges become easier to move across the interface, which has no amorphous layer, due to the weaker blocking effect to the charges for the thinner and ordered interface region.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: As a new material for the fabrication of radiation detectors, C0.9Zn0.1Te (CZT) has attracted considerable attention in the areas of X-ray imaging, airport security, medical CT, aerospace technology, etc. [1–4]. The devices made by CZT single crystals were reported to have favorable performance, which could be attributed to its large band gap, high resistivity, and superior charge-transport properties [5–8]. During the process of detector fabrication, the surface conditions will greatly affect the electrical and optical properties of CZT devices due to different contact characteristics formed between metal and CZT [9–11]. As a very important part of surface treatment, the chemical polishing process is usually carried out to remove the damage layer at the surface caused by mechanical polishing. It is known that a clean and defect-free surface with a tellurium-rich layer at the top can be obtained after the chemical etching process by using 2–5 % Br–MeOH solution [12–15]. However, the effect of chemical polishing on the interface structure between metal and CZT is still unclear.

In this study, atomic force spectroscopy (AFM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were employed to investigate the surface morphology and elemental concentration before and after the chemical polishing process. Au electrodes were prepared by using the vacuum evaporation method at the surface of CZT wafers after the AFM and SEM experiments. The interface structures between Au and CZT were studied by cross-sectional HRTEM. Meanwhile, I–V tests were also carried out for the Au/CZT contacts with different surface treatments in order to establish a relationship between the interface structures and electrical properties. Based on the results obtained, an interface structure model of Au/CZT is put forward.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: The CZT single crystal grown by the modified vertical Bridgman method was cut along the [111] direction into four samples with the dimension of 10 mm × 10 mm × 2 mm. Before the mechanical polishing was implemented, each sample was first dipped in HNO3/HF (1:1–3:1 volume ratio) solution for 1–2 s in order to determine the polarity of the (111) surface. The dark surface is the (111) A surface with Cd atoms at the top [16]. After the mechanical polishing process, three CZT samples were chemically polished in 2 % Br–MeOH solution for 2, 3, and 4 min, respectively, followed by rinsing with methanol to dissolve the Br remaining at the surface and then dried with nitrogen gas. AFM and SEM experiments were carried out on the AR-MFP-3D AFM and Zeiss Ultra FE-SEM after the surface treatment, respectively. Au electrodes were prepared at the surfaces of each sample with the thickness of 150 nm by using the vacuum evaporation method. A fast annealing process was implemented with the parameters of 200 ∘C and 5 min under N2 atmosphere for all samples. The I–V test was then carried out after the preparation of Au electrodes by using an Agilent 4155-C tester in order to find the differences of electrical properties for all the samples. Cross-sectional TEM specimens were prepared by bonding two parts of each sample together with a gold-plated surface face to face, followed by mechanical grinding along the direction perpendicular to the bonded interface to the thickness of 10 μm. A Gatan 691 precision Ar+ ion polishing system (PIPS) was employed to thin the samples suitable for TEM observation. During the procedure, a cold stage with the temperature of 100 K was used to avoid inducing artifacts to all the samples. The milling energy and angle were set to 3 keV and 7 degrees, respectively. JEM-3010 and JEM-2200FS transmission electron microscopes (TEMs) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were used to investigate the interface structure and elemental composition between Au electrode and CZT wafer. Finally, the Gatan Digital Micrograph software package was used to analyze the TEM images.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
It is known that the chemical polishing process has the function of removing the surface and sub-surface damage layer caused by mechanical polishing. For CZT, the related chemical reactions are as follows [16–18]:
1
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{Cd}_{0.9}\mathrm{Zn}_{0.1}\mathrm{Te}\ ( \mathrm{surface}) + \mathrm{Br}_{2}} \\ &{\quad = 0.9\mathrm{CdBr}_{2} + 0.1\mathrm{ZnBr}_{2} + \mathrm{Te},} \end{aligned}$$
2
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{Te} + 2\mathrm{Br}_{2} = \mathrm{TeBr}_{4}.} \end{aligned}$$ The reaction products CdBr2, ZnBr2, and TeBr4 will dissolve in methanol or bromine solution, leaving surplus Te at the surface of the CZT wafer. Therefore, the surface changes from Cd-rich to Te-rich after the chemical polishing process [16]. The changes of surface condition and elemental composition will lead to the differences of the interface structures and electrical properties between Au electrode and CZT wafer.

Before the film deposition, the AFM experiment was carried out to analyze the surface morphology before and after 2, 3, and 4 min etching, respectively, as shown in Fig. 1. In the area of 1×1 μm2, the sample without the etching process shows the coarsest surface with the roughness of 56.8 nm (Fig. 1a). Extremely high peaks with the height of about 40 nm can be seen from the image, indicating the poor surface flatness after mechanical polishing. A smoother surface can be obtained as the etching time elapses. The surface roughness dropped to 35.6, 31.2, and 30.4 nm after 2, 3, and 4 min etching, respectively. On the other hand, the raised parts of the CZT surface become duller as the etching time elapses, due to the occurrence of the chemical reaction often at places above or under the horizontal line of the sample surface. Similar results can be obtained through the SEM experiment. As shown in Fig. 2, the sample without chemical etching contains plenty of scratches indicated by arrows in the randomly selected area. The defects and scratches at the surface of CZT disappeared gradually as the etching process goes on, indicating that an excellent surface ready for film deposition has been obtained. The EDX spectra (accelerating voltage set to 10 kV) carried out from a randomly selected area for each sample are shown in Fig. 3. Meanwhile, the element composition of Cd, Zn, and Te is summarized in Table 1. It is found that the concentration of Te increases from 47.2 % to 50.6 % along with the etching process. Obviously, a Te enrichment surface is obtained after the chemical polishing process.
Fig. 1
Surface morphology of CZT samples under different chemical polishing times. (a) Before chemical polishing, (b) after 2 min polishing, (c) after 3 min polishing, (d) after 4 min polishing
Fig. 2
SEM images of CZT surface after different treatments. The scratches and defects gradually disappeared as the etching time elapsed. (a) Before chemical polishing, (b) After 2 min polishing, (c) After 3 min polishing, (d) After 4 min polishing
Fig. 3
EDX spectra of CZT samples with different surface treatments

The TEM experiment was carried out after the Au film deposition and the preparation of cross-sectional samples. Because of the difficulty in making TEM samples, only two specimens were prepared by using the as-mechanically polished and 4 min chemically polished samples in this study, regarded as samples A and B, respectively. Figure 4 shows the cross-sectional bright-field images of the interface structure between Au and CZT for both sample A and sample B. The columnar-shaped polycrystalline Au film with the thickness of about 150 nm can be seen clearly from both images. The average grain size of Au films is found as 1500–3000 nm2, much smaller than that of sample B (10000–16000 nm2), indicating different surface conditions of the two CZT samples. An amorphous layer with the thickness of about 5–10 nm is found between Au and CZT for sample A. A straighter and flatter interface without amorphous layer can be observed for sample B, illustrating that a smoother surface can be obtained after the chemical polishing process. On the other hand, no additional phase structure can be found between Au and CZT for both samples, indicating that no chemical reaction occurs during the film deposition.
Fig. 4
TEM bright-field images of Au/CZT interfaces for (a) sample A (mechanical polishing) and (b) sample B (mechanical polishing and chemical polishing). The amorphous layer with the thickness of about 5–10 nm was found at the interface of sample A

In order to analyze the interface structure in detail, HRTEM images were taken from the interface area for both samples, which are shown in Fig. 5. The thickness of the amorphous layer is found to vary from 3.5 nm to 11.2 nm with the change of surface roughness of CZT according to Fig. 5a. Since sample A is only mechanically polished, the thickness of the amorphous layer decreases and increases corresponding to the changes of CZT surface roughness. On the other hand, the amorphous layer can be considered as a mixture of Au and CZT. The annealing process which promotes the interdiffusion between the film and substrate is fully attributed to the mixing process, leading to the tendency of generating a transition layer with the lowest system energy. It can be assumed that the amorphization phenomenon occurs during the fabrication process of the electrode at the interface region. Crystallographically, both Au and CZT have fcc structure with the space group and lattice constant of
$Fm\bar{3}m$ and
$F\bar{4}3m$ , 4.079 Å and 6.424 Å, respectively. The lattice mismatch δ
f between Au and CZT can be defined as follows:
3
$$ \delta_{f} = (a_{\mathrm{CZT}} - a_{\mathrm{Au}})/a_{\mathrm{Au}}, $$ where a Au and a CZT are lattice parameters of Au and CZT, respectively. Therefore, the lattice mismatch for Au and CZT can be calculated as 57.5 %. The large lattice mismatch may be the reason for the formation of the amorphous layer, as it will lead to the energy reduction between the two lattices [19].
Fig. 5
HRTEM images for (a) sample A and (b) sample B. For sample A, the uneven surface of CZT without chemical polishing as well as annealing treatment causes the mixing of the amorphous layers. For sample B, the flat interface with a 1.2 nm lattice mismatch layer is found between Au and CZT

Compared with sample A, the interface structure for sample B is quite different. A straighter interface without amorphous layer between Au and CZT can be seen clearly from Fig. 5b. In other words, the chemical polishing process leads to the formation of a smoother interface. Meanwhile, a lattice-mismatch layer with the thickness of 1.2 nm (much thinner than the amorphous layer) is found between Au and CZT. The lattice fringes can be seen clearly at the mismatch layer, indicating the orderliness of the layer compared with the amorphous one. The charges are considered to move across the interface for sample B much more easily, as the transition area is thinner and more regular. It is a key factor for the formation of the ohmic contact for Au and CZT. Meanwhile, a surplus Te layer formed at the surface of CZT after the chemical polishing process has lower resistivity (approximately three orders of magnitude lower than the sample without the chemical etching process), causing the decrease of contact resistance [14, 20]. That is another reason for the easier formation of the ohmic contact between Au and CZT wafer after chemical polishing. The lattice mismatch calculated from Eq. (3) is 9.2 % (a Te =4.456 Å) for sample B, which is much smaller than that of sample A. Hence, the amorphous layer is unlikely to form at the interface of sample B due to the smaller lattice mismatch caused by the existence of the Te layer after the chemical polishing process.

The EDX measurements were carried out for both samples at the position of Au film, interface layer and CZT substrate, respectively. The spectra of six points marked with I, II and III in Fig. 5 for both samples are shown in Fig. 6. Meanwhile, the elemental compositions are summarized in Table 2. Cu peaks at the energy positions of 8.03 keV and 8.91 keV in the spectra have almost the same intensities for each point. This can fully be attributed to the existence of the copper grid and the specimen holder used in this study. The diffusion is found for both samples according to the appearance of Cd, Zn, and Te at the position of point III. According to Fig. 6a and Table 2, the amorphous layer is confirmed as a mixture of CZT and Au atoms for sample A with the elemental concentration for Cd, Zn, Te, and Au of 31.8 %, 2.3 %, 37.6 %, and 28.3 % respectively. The annealing process is fully attributed to the mixing for all elements. For the spectra of sample B, shown in Fig. 6b, Te enrichment is found very seriously at the surface after chemical polishing, as the concentration of Te changed from 39.8 % (point I) to 56.1 % (point II) according to Table 2. The interdiffusion caused by the annealing process is found for both samples according to the existence of Au and Cd, Zn, Te at matrix and film sides, respectively. According to previous research works [21–24], the interdiffusion process is a key factor affecting the electrical properties between metal and CZT. On the other hand, the elemental concentration for Zn almost remains the same for all the six points, indicating a relatively extreme diffusion for Zn to the Au film compared with Cd and Te. The smallest atomic radius for Zn is probably the reason for this phenomenon.
Fig. 6
The EDX spectra of the points marked with I, II and III in Fig. 5 for both samples. For sample A (a), the amorphous layer is found to be a mixture of CZT and Au. For sample B (b), Te enrichment is discovered at the surface of CZT after the chemical polishing process

In order to find the relationship between the interface structure and electrical properties under different surface treatments, the current–voltage (I–V) curves were measured for all the four samples, shown in Fig. 7. Compared with the as-mechanically polished one, the current at both 100 V and −100 V for the sample after 4 min etching is more than 10 times higher. The lower contact resistance is probably due to the existence of the surplus Te layer after the chemical polishing process. Each curve in Fig. 7 is fitted by using the non-linear function
4
$$ I(V) = aV^{b}, $$ where a is a constant and b represents the ohmic contact coefficient. If b is closer to 1, the ohmic contact property is better [21]. Table 3 shows the current at 100 V and the calculated ohmic contact coefficient for each sample. It can be seen that the current becomes larger after the chemical polishing treatment. Meanwhile, the ohmic contact coefficients are much closer to 1. It is obvious that the charges will become easier to move across the interface due to the orderliness of the interface structure between Au and CZT after the chemical polishing process.
Fig. 7
I–V characteristics of Au/CZT contact with different surface treatments

Based on the results obtained above, we can summarize the Au/CZT interface structure model under different surface treatments, as shown in Fig. 8. As there is no obvious change for the structure and elemental composition when carrying out more than 4 min chemical etching, here we only consider the interface structure model before and after 4 min chemical polishing, regarded as samples A and B, which is the same as the discussion of the TEM results. The black balls, white balls, and shadowed balls indicate Cd (Zn) atoms, Te atoms, and Au atoms, respectively. It is found that the surface of sample A has a damage layer after mechanical polishing, causing the lattice to be broken at the surface, as shown in Fig. 8a. After the Au electrode is prepared, the damaged lattice is easier to break off due to the existence of surface stress, forming the amorphous layers of CZT. At the same time, the Au lattice also breaks off due to the large mismatch between Au and CZT, leading to the formation of an Au amorphous layer. The annealing process is considered to endow the trend of mixing with each other for both amorphous layers, as shown in Fig. 8b. This layer would greatly block the charge transport across the interface, causing the increase of contact resistance. Therefore, it is unfavorable for the formation of an ohmic contact with the existence of the amorphous layer. On the other hand, the surface of sample B with the Te layer at the top has less stress or broken lattice, as shown in Fig. 8c. When the Au electrode is prepared, the smaller mismatch between Au and Te will not lead to the appearance of an amorphous layer; instead, a thinner lattice-mismatch layer forms at the interface area, as shown in Fig. 8d. Compared with sample A, the thinner and ordered mismatch layer will less likely to block the charges moving across the interface region, leading to the optimization of ohmic contact properties and the reduction of contact resistance. It is the reason for reducing the contact resistance and improving the ohmic contact properties after chemical polishing treatment for CZT single crystals.
Fig. 8
Schematic diagram of Au/CZT (111) interface structure model for both samples. Only mechanically polished sample (a) before and (b) after contact with Au electrode; after chemically polishing the sample (c) before and (d) after contact with the Au electrode

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: The effect of the chemical polishing process on the interface structure and electrical properties between Au and CZT (111) A has been studied in detail. It was found that the surface roughness dropped significantly as the etching process went on according to the AFM results. The excellent polishing effect of Br–MeOH on the surface of CZT has been confirmed by the SEM experiment, as defects and scratches almost disappeared after 4 min polishing. Meanwhile, a Te enrichment layer was found at the surface of CZT after the chemical polishing from the EDX test. The existence of the layer is considered to be the reason for the lower contact resistance between Au and CZT according to the I–V test. The TEM experiment was carried out after the Au deposition process to investigate the interface structure by using the as-mechanically polished and 4 min chemically polished samples. For the only mechanical polished sample, an amorphous layer which is considered as a mixture of CZT and Au has been found at the interface area. The annealing process is regarded as promoting the mixing. The formation reason for the amorphous layer is found to be the large lattice mismatch (57.5 %) between Au and CZT. On the other hand, the chemical polishing process has the function of removing the amorphous layer at the interface region due to the formation of the Te layer at the surface of CZT. Compared with Au and CZT, the lattice mismatch is smaller for Au and Te (9.2 %), which will form a thinner lattice mismatch layer instead of the amorphous one. Corresponding to the I–V test, the ohmic contact property was better as the chemical polishing process went on. It indicates that the charges become easier to pass through the interface without the amorphous layer due to its weaker blocking effect.
